articles.headline: Betsy DeVos Confirmed as Education Secretary; Pence Breaks Tie
articles.snippet: The vote on Tuesday was believed to be the first in Senate history in which the vice president was called in to break a tie on a cabinet nomination.
articles.abstract: The vote on Tuesday was believed to be the first in Senate history in which the vice president was called in to break a tie on a cabinet nomination.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Betsy DeVos, a wealthy Republican donor with almost no experience in public education, was confirmed by the Senate as the nation’s education secretary on Tuesday, but only with the help of a historic tiebreaking vote from Vice President Mike Pence after weeks of protests and two defections within her own party.
articles.byline: By Emmarie Huetteman and Yamiche Alcindor

articles.headline: Appeals Court Panel Appears Skeptical of Trump’s Travel Ban
articles.snippet: Three federal judges were considering a lower court’s ruling that allowed previously barred travelers and immigrants from seven predominantly Muslim countries to enter the country.
articles.abstract: Three federal judges were considering a lower court’s ruling that allowed previously barred travelers and immigrants from seven predominantly Muslim countries to enter the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Justice Department lawyer on Tuesday said courts should not second-guess President Trump’s targeted travel ban, drawing skepticism from a three-judge federal appeals panel weighing the limits of executive authority in cases of national security.

articles.headline: Is News of Terror Attacks Underplayed? Experts Say No
articles.snippet: President Trump’s claim runs counter to what has long been considered a given: that abundant media coverage has given terrorists the attention they crave.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s claim runs counter to what has long been considered a given: that abundant media coverage has given terrorists the attention they crave.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Margaret Thatcher famously declared that “we must try to find ways to starve the terrorist and the hijacker of the oxygen of publicity on which they depend.”

articles.headline: For-Profit Law School Faces Crisis After Losing Federal Loans
articles.snippet: Charlotte Law’s struggles highlight the questions being raised over for-profit law schools and the sky-high amounts that students are borrowing for their education.
articles.abstract: Charlotte Law’s struggles highlight the questions being raised over for-profit law schools and the sky-high amounts that students are borrowing for their education.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Toni Valentine, a third-year law student, wanted to know if her school, Charlotte School of Law, was going to close, but it was not telling her.

articles.headline: Joyous Africans Take to the Rails, With China’s Help
articles.snippet: A new railway line from Djibouti to Ethiopia has showcased China’s effort to extend its influence, with aid and expertise, throughout Africa.
articles.abstract: A new railway line from Djibouti to Ethiopia has showcased China’s effort to extend its influence, with aid and expertise, throughout Africa.
articles.lead_paragraph: DJIBOUTI — The 10:24 a.m. train out of Djibouti’s capital drew some of the biggest names in the Horn of Africa last month. Serenaded by a chorus of tribal singers, the crush of African leaders, European diplomats and pop icons climbed the stairs of the newly built train station and merrily jostled their way into the pristine, air-conditioned carriages making their inaugural run.

articles.headline: White House Weighs Terrorist Designation for Muslim Brotherhood
articles.snippet: The Brotherhood, with millions of followers, is the oldest Islamist group in the Middle East, and designating it as a terrorist group would roil the region.
articles.abstract: The Brotherhood, with millions of followers, is the oldest Islamist group in the Middle East, and designating it as a terrorist group would roil the region.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s advisers are debating an order intended to designate the Muslim Brotherhood as a foreign terrorist organization, targeting the oldest and perhaps most influential Islamist group in the Middle East.

articles.headline: Yemen Withdraws Permission for U.S. Antiterror Ground Missions
articles.snippet: The suspension of commando operations in Yemen is a setback for President Trump, who says he wants to take a more aggressive approach against Islamic militants.
articles.abstract: The suspension of commando operations in Yemen is a setback for President Trump, who says he wants to take a more aggressive approach against Islamic militants.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Angry at the civilian casualties incurred last month in the first commando raid authorized by President Trump, Yemen has withdrawn permission for the United States to run Special Operations ground missions against suspected terrorist groups in the country, according to American officials.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: German Automakers Step Up to Silicon Valley Challenge
articles.snippet: BMW, Daimler and Volkswagen are striving with increasing urgency to ride the digital wave sweeping the industry, before it rolls over them.
articles.abstract: BMW, Daimler and Volkswagen are striving with increasing urgency to ride the digital wave sweeping the industry, before it rolls over them.
articles.lead_paragraph: WOLFSBURG, Germany — One of the first things Ole Harms did after taking over Volkswagen’s new ride-hailing start-up was leave town.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Mark Scott

articles.headline: Why Silicon Valley Wouldn’t Work Without Immigrants
articles.snippet: To get the very best people in the world, tech companies must look beyond American shores.
articles.abstract: To get the very best people in the world, tech companies must look beyond American shores.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The workers of Silicon Valley make unlikely revolutionaries. As a group, they are relatively wealthy, well educated and well connected.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Nominee Calls Trump’s Attacks on Judiciary ‘Demoralizing’
articles.snippet: President Trump escalated his feud with the courts over his travel ban, saying the judges had failed to grasp concepts even “a bad high school student would understand.”
articles.abstract: President Trump escalated his feud with the courts over his travel ban, saying the judges had failed to grasp concepts even “a bad high school student would understand.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Judge Neil M. Gorsuch, President Trump’s nominee for the Supreme Court, privately expressed dismay on Wednesday over Mr. Trump’s increasingly aggressive attacks on the judiciary, calling the president’s criticism of independent judges “demoralizing” and “disheartening.”
